user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_register_generic_device:
```c
int metal_register_generic_device(struct metal_device *device)
{
	if (!device->name || !strlen(device->name) ||
	    device->num_regions > METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS)
		return -EINVAL;

	device->bus = &metal_generic_bus;
	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_device_list,
			    &device->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strlen(device->name)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment calls the standard library function strlen(device->name), not metal_register_generic_device itself. There is no direct or indirect call from metal_register_generic_device back to itself in this snippet. (A violation would only occur if strlen or another called function somehow invoked metal_register_generic_device, which is not the case here.)
